text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so I just 
got back from my trip to Thailand still a little

jet-lagged but while I was home I got to have 
so many simple home-cooked meals made mostly by

my grandmother and so now I'm all inspired by 
it and I want to share with you a recipe that

is the epitome of a simple home-cooked meal so we 
are going to make kai jiew moo sub and kai jiew is omelet

and moo sub is ground pork so simple ground pork 
omelet that is so delicious and it's definitely

something that I make if I need dinner in five 
minutes and I have very few things in the fridge

so let's get started all right this is going 
to be the simplest recipe ever so I'm going

to go in with two large eggs and I learned how 
to make kto mousse up I must have been I don't

know six I mean as young as I could could have 
been to cook and now I'm going to season this

with a little bit of fish sauce this is standard 
and the simplest kto is basically just eggs and

fish sauce that you could stop here and you 
have your basic ideal but I like to act add

actually a little bit of oyster sauce I think 
it adds a little something sewn into it and by

the way moister sauce in squeeze bottle is how I 
always store it because it makes it easy to pour

and measure a dash of white pepper completely 
optional I'm just trying to fancy up a simple

meal a little bit to put your heading some pepper 
all right get that beat up and now the ground pork

you've got your protein break that up there you 
don't want big chunks because then it won't it'll

get lumps in the omelets just to add a little 
freshness I'm going to add some chopped green

onions again completely optional but I think you 
know it makes it look prettier too a little bit

of greenery in there and that's it it's done you 
just have to cook it now all right so I am going

to use a little nonstick pan here and I actually 
like to you the pan that is just the size that

you want the omelette to be so for this a little 
8 inch like this is perfect nonstick is helpful

because we all know you know eggs and sticky pans 
can be bad news you can do this in a walk as well

normally in Thailand we do this in a wok but I do 
find that it's easier to flip when I use a saute

pan so you want this to get hot so you know to 
test you just drop in a little bit of egg and if

it puffs up kind of like bania it's probably 
ready to go and push it a little bit further

because this is cold so I'm gonna let it heat up 
a little bit more look it's tiny little omelettes

okay here we go there you want to hear it sizzle 
as you drop it in and now just in the first few

seconds I'm going to just stir it a little bit and 
it just helps the omelet cook a little more evenly

but don't do this too much because you don't 
want scrambled it right just in the beginning

so you distribute that first a little bit of 
cooked eggs and now you let it cook you want to

make sure the heat is not too high because then 
you will burn the bottom before the top is firm

enough to flip and so you want to err on the side 
of heat being too low okay because you can always

cook it a little longer but if it's burnt then 
it's bird so what I like to do sometimes also

is just to pour the liquid egg underneath helps 
it cook a little faster there you go and now you

just want to be checking the bottom to make sure 
you want a nice golden brown you don't want you

know French style pale yellow omelette here Thai 
people we like our eggs browned all right it's

ready to flip now before I flip I'm just gonna 
get rid of the last little bit of liquid so when

I flip it doesn't splatter too much make sure 
it's loose before you flip Hey there we go Hey

look how pretty that is and we're 15 seconds away 
from this being done so get your rice get your

rice because you want to have this with rice and 
we'll turn this off now because the residual heat

from the pan will keep everything cooking this 
is like the perfect personal sized omelet two

eggs you're eating by yourself this is perfect 
oh yes perfect dinner for one right here mmm

yes this just tastes like home to me because it's 
it's just this flavor that I associated with just

being a kid going up in Thailand and I really 
want you to try it so that you can experience

this like Thai childhood flavor of mine and 
it's so easy once you make this you're going

to be returning to it again and again and again 
because you'll be addicted to how fast and easy

this is and as a trick if you want to have 
ground pork ready to go just freeze it in

the freezer but in a very thin layer like in 
a ziplock bag right thin and then when you're

ready just break off a chunk and it'll thaw in 
no time so I hope you enjoy that oh I almost

forgot a lot of people like to eat this with 
Si Racha hot sauce but to me this is so well

seasoned with that or softer sauce that I like 
just like this but if you want a little sriracha

is a classic pairing so the recipe is on hot I 
kitchen calm when you make this send me a photo

on Facebook Twitter Instagram I love seeing 
your photos and if you haven't subscribed to

the show please do so right here and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
you
